revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name = CA-15 "Kangaroo" |image = CA-15.jpg |caption = }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type = Fighter |manufacturer = [[Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation]] |designer = |first flight = 4 March 1946 |introduced = |retired = 1950 |produced = |number built = 1 |status = Scrapped |unit cost = |primary user = [[Royal Australian Air Force]] |more users = |developed from = |variants with their own articles = }} |} The '''CAC CA-15''', also known unofficially as the '''CAC Kangaroo''', was an [[Australia]]n [[Propeller (aircraft)|propeller]]-driven [[fighter aircraft]] designed by the [[Commonwealth Aircraft Corporation]] (CAC) during [[World War II]]. Due to protracted development, the project was not completed until after the war, and was cancelled after flight testing, when the advent of [[jet aircraft]] was imminent.
==Design and development== [[File:CA-15-Crash-Landing.jpg|thumb|300px|The CA-15 after crash landing at RAAF Point Cook]] During 1943, following the success of CAC and chief designer [[Fred David]], in rapidly designing and mass-producing the small [[CAC Boomerang|Boomerang fighter]] for the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF), CAC began design work on a fully fledged [[interceptor aircraft|interceptor]] and [[escort fighter|bomber escort]].
Although the CA-15 bore a superficial resemblance to the [[North American P-51 Mustang]],<ref name="AI p179">''Air Enthusiast'' October 1972, p. 179.</ref> the CAC design was not based directly on the U.S. aircraft and had quite different performance objectives and dimensions.<ref name="AI p179"/> For instance, David had been impressed by assessments of captured [[Focke-Wulf Fw 190]]s<ref name= "Ross 1995">Ross 1995, p. 321.</ref> and intended using a [[radial engine]] (see below) rather than the [[Inline engine (aviation)|inline engine]]s used in fighters like the Mustang. In fact, development of the CA-15 was slowed by a recommendation from CAC head [[Lawrence Wackett]], that the company build Mustangs under licence, rather than bear the cost of developing a unique design. By the later stages of its development, it was believed that the CA-15 would have capabilities enabling it to replace the P-51.<ref name="Crick, 2003" /><!--see talk---{{Failed verification|date=February 2011}}---->
At first, the CAC designers planned to use the 2,300 hp (1,715 kW) radial [[Pratt & Whitney R-2800]], with a [[turbocharger]]. However, that engine became unavailable, <ref name="Wilson">{{cite book|last1=Wilson|first1=Stewart|title=Military Aircraft of Australia|date=1994|publisher=Aerospace Publications|location=Weston Creek, Australia|isbn=1875671080|pages=216|accessdate=30 August 2016}}</ref>causing further delays in development, and it was decided to fit an in-line [[Rolls-Royce Griffon]] Mk 61 (2,035 hp/1,517 kW). Engines for a prototype were leased from Rolls-Royce.<ref name="Crick, 2003"/> It was intended that any production engines would have a three-speed [[supercharger]].
==Operational history== [[File:CA-15 from Lincoln.jpg|thumb|300px|The CA-15, piloted by Flt Lt J.A.L. Archer, over Melbourne, photographed from the rear turret of an [[Avro Lincoln]] bomber.]] Development was further slowed by the end of the war, with the prototype flying for the first time on 4 March 1946,<ref name="Wilson" /> and was flown by CAC test pilot Jim Schofield, who also flew the first Australian built P-51. The prototype was assigned RAAF serial number A62-1001. According to aviation historian Darren Crick, it achieved a calibrated level flight speed of 448 mph (721 km/h) at 26,400 ft (8,046 m). Test flights came to an abrupt ending when [[Flight Lieutenant|Flt Lt]] J. A. L. Archer suffered a hydraulic failure (later found to be a leaking ground test gauge) on approach to Point Cook on 10 December 1946, which left him no choice but to orbit and burn off fuel. The main gear was only halfway down and unable to be retracted or lowered any further but the tail wheel was down and locked. On landing, the tail wheel struck the airstrip first causing the aircraft to porpoise and finally, the airscoop dug in. The aircraft settled back on the fuselage and skidded to a stop, heavily damaged.<ref name="Crick, 2003">Crick 2003{{page needed|date=December 2012}}</ref> After repairs at CAC, the aircraft was returned to [[Aircraft Research and Development Unit RAAF|ARDU]] in 1948. Archer reportedly achieved a speed of 502.2 mph (803 km/h) over [[Melbourne]], after levelling out of a dive of 4,000 ft (1,200 m), on 25 May 1948.
By this time, however, it was clear that jet aircraft had far greater potential and no further examples of the CA-15 were built. The prototype was scrapped in 1950, and the engines were returned to Rolls-Royce.<ref name="Crick, 2003"/>
==Operators== ;{{AUS}} *[[Royal Australian Air Force]]
